reviews.review_text: This is a good take on the 'bullet hell' genre. Not as infuriating as most of the Japanese varients of 'bullet hell'. It's still frustrating enough to make you want to punch the screen, yet addicting and enjoyable enough to make you say 'just one more try...' about 83 times before you realize it's 0330, and you have to work the next day.  Great for playing in short spurts, as you can easily pick up for 10 minutes, die a few times, and then go about your business.

The game has a few interesting ideas for the bullet-hell/twin-stick shooter genre-hybrid, but it lacks focus and struggles to follow it's own rules resulting in a highly unsatisfying experience.  Here was my experience.  First thing that struck me was the obnoxiously flashy menu screen. I mean, the bloom rendered the menus unreadable! But perhaps it is my monitor that isn't perfectly calibrated that is causing the issue. I can try to look past that. So let me change the resolution so I can enjoy it in full-screen... wait a minute. Why is there an unsatisfying selection of screen resolutions? The game just reeks laziness now. If your monitor resolution isn't the top 4 most common resolutions, gg to full-screen experience.  I still decided to give the game a shot. I tried the tutorial, but it left me feeling very confused about many things. Why add in the drilling ability? The spinning ability? When would I use each one? What are you talking about 'hoops in the nebula'? Perhaps if I play a few levels I will come to understand... Nope. After playing a few levels, I didn't even understand how I died most of the time nor understand what I should have done to stay alive. Maybe the fun is in figuring all this out? But first I got to use my points to level up.  What should I level up? What does each of these do? The description doesn't clarify most of the time nor can I see how the leveling affects my ship. The leveling process is so unsatisfying, I don't even care what I level up as I often feel no sense of progress. Also, why are there two play/back commands in the level up menu? Such lazy menu design.  After playing and dying so many times, I decide to refer to the library archive in hopes of reading up on the enemies I faced. 'Know thy enemy' right? Well, it would make a lot more sense if they actually placed images of the enemies so I know what they are talking about instead of focusing on trying to be funny. For the record, their attempt at humor was so invasive, there was nothing funny about it.  I keep playing hoping I get over that hump to where I can start to have fun, but the more I play, the more I realize how rotten the game is. Due to randomly generated levels, each playthrough is unique, but it's also not satisfying because the difficulty feels very artificial and removes the feeling of progress. Also, by adding shields that absorb damage in a bullet-hell game, it removes the threat bullets have at all. I'll bet it was introduced because when things get too intense, all the flashy effects makes it impossible to tell what the hell is going on. So rather than toning down the effects, they removed the core of what made bullet-hell bullet-hell. It doesn't stop there though. What makes difficult games fun? Because the game lays out rules, and defeats you while following those rules. And the simpler the rules, the better. As such, when you die, you know exactly why you died and that reason was you. The game didn't cheap-shot you. Due to all the elements added to a supposedly simple genre, many times it's not clear why you died, and it breaks it's rules quite often, removing any fun from the challenge.  So in conclusion, the game ebbs feebly with nice ideas and flashy effects, but the game lacks much needed focus for the experience to be satisfying. Avoid this game if you can.

I've had a lot of problems with this game. Now I know why they were giving it away for free. First off, the game starts out in a dinky window. If you switch to 1080p resolution it's STILL in a window. If you switch to fullscreen it starts off looking OK, and then winds up like the screen is zoomed in too far and you can only see about 80% of the game (which takes up 100% of the screen).  OK, so you think you should quit and start over. CRASH. Really Big Sky has stopped working. Press this button to do nothing or press this other button to wait 30 seconds and THEN do nothing. Start the game over... nope it's still zoomed in way too far. There is just no resolution option that feels good so after a lot of fidgeting you switch back to the original windowed mode.  OK then, so let's try to actually play the game. It gives some really hokey tutorial about how you can use one stick to move and the other stick to shoot (or alternately explains WASD and mouse) while being narrated in this really bland voice that barely stands out amongst the game's bland soundtrack. The graphics themselves have a muted tone to them as well so it's like the whole game is trying really hard to be the visual equivalent of oatmeal or rice cakes.   I started this up thinking it would be another good shooter like Syder Arcade, but instead it came out like a really poor imitation of the genre. Maybe I'll change my mind after more than 10 minutes with it but at the moment the game has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off so much that 10 minutes was more than enough.  EDIT: Ok, so I have given it another run and... I still don't really recommend it.   For starters, the menu is actually kinda confusing. There's a set of options that looks like you should be able to press a button to toggle it from one selection to the other, but any button you press will exit the menu. Instead there's an arrow pointing in a direction and you have to press the analog stick in that direction to get it to change. For some reason I expected it to be the opposite (that the arrow showed the current condition and pressing in the opposite direction would change it).  The game has this annoying game mechanic where you have to Drill through 'planets' at random points in the game. You accomplish this by pressing a button that brings the drill around to the front of the ship and while it's there you can't fire.   It seems like the only thing the drill is good for is certain planet sized stuff, so you can't drill through an enemy (unless it's taking up the whole screen), and in general the game has poor conveyance of what is something to be shot and what is something to be collected. I wound up dying a few times because I thought it was a powerup to pick up and instead I collided with an enemy or something in the background.  The announcer is apparently going for the 'I'm talking to you from a distance over a radio' type voice effects, but that actually made it quite hard to understand. Combine that with the fact that he's British and sometimes I hear something that sounds like (to my American ears) 'Cor Blimey, crikey he's gone off his nutter, knees up mother brown. Off with his head, and mind your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for that barmy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Mate! Oy!' And that's if I understand anything he said at all.  The backgrounds in the game are nice to look at, but it's all quite distracting and it's hard to tell which are the important game elements and what is just scenery. I died a couple of times to stuff I thought I should have been able to fly by.  The music is all technoish and the flashing lights are reminiscent of a rave, but it still seems very muted somehow. So far nothing has made me feel psyched up to take on the enemy.   I don't know yet if there's a way to get the game to look good in full screen. I didn't want to risk it crashing on me again so I made sure to play it windowed.   The game's only saving graces from what I can see are the unlockable game modes and the fact that you can use your points scored in the last game to buy stats for your ship. At least this way you don't feel like your time was completely wasted and that you're somehow making progress.   That doesn't sound like enough to keep me interested in this game long term though. It's good for a 10-15 minute game here and there.

Really Big Sky is a side-scrolling space shooter/bullet hell game where you go through procedurally-generated levels, blasting enemies and upgrading your ship for the next time you play.  It seems like this game has a lot of strategic depth to it, but I'm having a hard time telling for sure because the game doesn't tell you anything. The tutorial is fine for getting the basic controls, but the game is terrible at describing anything else. I have little idea what most of the upgrades actually do, so I can't really make informed decisions. It's cool to blast stuff and all, but I feel like 90% of the game is going over my head, and the game itself is just fine with that.  The game, at least, is very pretty, and the music is nice to listen to. The narrator's somewhat entertaining. The controls really suck at first, and I had to do a lot of customization in the options before they were even passable.  Overall, this game seems like it has decent gameplay, but it's completely ruined by the poor execution of the rest of the game. I wouldn't recommend Really Big Sky to anyone but the most enthusiastic of bullet hell game fans.

I got this game when it was offered for free and have no regrets.  If you like bullet hell, shoot-em-up style gameplay, then you will really enjoy this game.  The aesthetics are wonderful, it reminds me a lot of geometry wars with all the crazy special effects. There is a lot of color and it can be overwhelming at times - the high activity on the screen can make it difficult to track where you are, enemy projectices, etc. The music is very good and adds to the intensity of the gameplay.   The controls are very simple, and the learning curve is minimal. There is a tutorial in the beginning of the game that is quick and very helpful. I find the narrator to be a bit annoying, but it is possible to turn the narration off.   Grinding in this game is actually quite easy because you can get a lot of credits very quickly with each game session (thanks to the score multipliers). The upgrading is simple, and they are mostly offensive-based.   There is a unique mechanic in this game where you will periodically encounter planets/asteroids. To pass them, you have to switch your weapon to your drill, allowing you to travel through to the other side. Inside the planets, there will be random bonuses like increased weapon spread, ship speed, score multiplier, etc - drilling through these will give you the bonuses. While your drill is active, your weapons will also charge, allowing you to shoot massive beams when you switch back to them.   As the game progresses, there will be times where your super boost activates, propelling you forward at a blinding speed. This is easily one of the most dangerous parts, because it is very easy to crash straight into an enemy projectile, or worse, any enemy ship.  The boss battles are not too difficult, but the game remains challenging, especially when the screen is filled with weapon effects.  Very fun game, pick it up if you like shoot-em-ups.  Recommend!

This game has some issues. I haven't played much of the game, but these issues are clear and apparent within the first few minutes of gameplay.  The tutorial goes from peaceful control learning... To suddenly throwing you into the gameplay at a super-fast pace and you dying. That's okay... for some people. I'm one of those kinds of people, but not everyone is.  Secondly, the game's SUPA TECHNO LIGHTING screws with the gameplay. The effects hide an enemy somewhere and then you die.  By the way... The nice British narrator swears every time you die. He says t**, a**, and a number of other things. This is utter mindless garbage. Swearing is OK, but please make an option to NOT have it. Some menus even have curse words like d*** right on them (Peaceful mode says 'Throw in your god d*** towel.' Are you joking me? Nothing lets you know this game has that. Nothing. The game looks fine for kids, the tutorial is fine, then the game decides to showcase lots of cursing. The issue I have with this is that there is no 'noswear' option, no warning of this, and it is always constant and blatant. Goodness.  Back to the gameplay.  Everything in this game will kill you within a small number of hits. Lasers or ships alike, they will kill you. Instantly, on the lower levels. Once you start upgrading stuff, you will start making it to bosses... Maybe... And then you will die. Half of the 'enemies' on screen cannot be killed, half the objects cannot be destroyed. Most stuff you have to drill through. By the way... THE TUTORIAL MENTIONS NONE OF THIS. It gives you a short flying tutorial, and then just says 'screw you, MAJOR BLAM BLAM TIME.'  And yes. Half the enemies cannot be killed in a twin-stick SHOOTER. This game is more like a runner.  Other gripes. The game's HYPER TECHNO GRAPHICS strike again with performance. On lower cards, it will lag out for a few frames (usually resulting in massive damage / death). No health bar (sure, I'm one hit dead when I start, but could I get a shield bar?). No indication of certain enemies and what they do. Obsessively overintensive lighting that gets in the way (such lighting can be done without messing up the gameplay. Try Beat Hazard Ultra). Swearing is annoying as anything. Narrator repeats the same few lines (and I like his voice! They botched him up.) This game is not only difficult, but also punishing and annoying in almost every way. Game gives no indication or lesson on what will kill you, and with how obsessively good the AI is, you will never know.  So do I recommend this? If you're a child, no. Lots of swearing. If you're someone looking to cause carnage... No. The only carnage is your own. If you're someone who doesn't have the best gfx card. Nope, lag will kill you. If you're looking for a good experience of skill... Nope, this is just punishing. The list goes on. The shoot 'em up has been seeing a resurgence lately in the land of indies. As technology has blossomed, so too has the love of flashy lights and cool explosions. Really Big Sky lives for the ridiculous and the flashy, with spinning psychedelic dinosaur heads and gorgeous 80's inspired everything to really keep the mesmerization of those watching all of that stuff explode in colorful, saturated bursts.  Whomever the art designer was, they must've really liked the most recent Star Trek films because my god is everything glare-y and saturated. Most of the time, it's gorgeous watching the chaos unfold on screen, but sometimes the overwhelming brightness of explosions or attacks and the sheer information overload can disorient and end an impressive run without even knowing what exactly killed you. It can be frustrating, but it's hard not to love a game so charmingly bombastic.   There is a lot of inspired ideas implemented into this little indie title, and more than enough to keep someone engaged to see everything it has to offer. Randomized encounters and an increasing difficulty, along with permanent upgrades and so forth adds further to the fun, even if it is fairly easy to max everything out quickly. The speed in which things are unlocked can be fairly cathartic, and wiping out swarms of T-Rex skulls is never not satisfying, but you will see just about everything before too long.  It's fun, it's wildly stupid, and it's fairly cheap and on sale often. Are there better games? Yes. Of course there are. But as a schmup, there are few so willing to embrace the insane, I can't help but love this one. Drilling planets at an insane speed is also one of the coolest things ever. Definitely looking forward to whatever else this studio releases.
